problem: What is the value of $c$ if $x\cdot(3x+1)<c$ if and only when $x\in \left(-\frac{7}{3},2\right)$?
solution:
When $x\in \left(-\frac{7}{3},2\right)$, we have $x\cdot(3x+1)-c<0$. This means that $x(3x+1)-c=0$ at $x=-\frac{7}{3}$ and $x=2$. We now know that $x(3x+1)-c=0$ is a quadratic equation with roots at $x=-\frac{7}{3}$ and $x=2$, and we want to use these roots to find a quadratic of the same form as the problem.  $x=-\frac{7}{3}$ gives us $(3x+7)=0$ and $x=2$ gives us $(x-2)=0$. \begin{align*}
x(3x+1)-c&=(3x+7)(x-2)\\
&=3x^2+x-14\\
&=x(3x+1)-14.
\end{align*} So, $c=\boxed{14}$.
model_solution:
We have $x\cdot(3x+1)<c$ if and only if $x\in\left(-\frac{7}{3},2\right)$. 

First, we evaluate the function at $x=-\frac{7}{3}$: 
\begin{align*}
f\left(-\frac{7}{3}\right) &= -\frac{7}{3}\cdot\left(3\cdot\left(-\frac{7}{3}\right)+1\right) \\
&= -\frac{7}{3}\cdot\left(-7+1\right) \\
&= -\frac{7}{3}\cdot(-6) \\
&= \frac{42}{3} \\
&= 14.
\end{align*}

Then we evaluate the function at $x=2$:
\begin{align*}
f(2) &= 2\cdot(3\cdot2+1) \\
&= 2\cdot(6+1) \\
&= 2\cdot7 \\
&= 14.
\end{align*}

So we have that the value of the function at the endpoints of the interval is 14. 
Because the function $f(x)=x\cdot(3x+1)$ is increasing for $x\in(-\frac{7}{3},2)$ 
and $c=f(-\frac{7}{3})=f(2)=14$, we have that 
$$x\cdot(3x+1)<14.$$

Therefore, the value of $c$ is $\boxed{14}.$
